content:
ber 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Within an hour, Nuclear Throne became my all time favorite game. Having over 200 games on Steam and having played many more on handhelds, consoles, and yes, even phones, I can safely say that this game is worth thirty times what it costs as of now.Let's start with the gameplay. Oh, the gameplay. Every gun is varied and somewhat useful and satisfying to use, the characters and how you play them vary vastly despite having little differences between them, And by satisfying, I mean oh, good lord. Let me quantify this. Have you ever played a game in which a shotgun feels the same as a pistol? That game lacks what some call, "crunch". Nuclear Throne is naught but crunchy. Killing with the basic revolver is satisfying if a bit difficult, most of your friends will find differing opinions on characters to use, and finally, the game's FUN. No questions asked, straight-up FUN.Now how about the graphics and sound? This game has one of, if not THE best pixel aesthetic I've seen. Everything pops out from the background and it feels alive. It's not muddled down by the browns and the greys; you can tell what's what almost all of the time. Oh, and the music is spectacular. It's one of the best soundtracks I've heard in a long time and every song or ambient track is somewhat enjoyable.How about the length? Well, depending on your skill level, it could take you over 500 hours to even make it to the final boss once. However, if you're skilled enough, you could loop twice within 40 hours. It really does vary on skill level, so I wouldn't say much about it. Just know that no matter how many times you try, you'll come back to the game.In essence, this game is fantastic beyond belief. Vlambeer is a fantastic developer that I would very much enjoy to purchase from in the future. They've released several other games that I'd recommend as well, too, so check them out if you can!...except for Super Crate Box. That one was just frustrating.

Early Access Review
								About as difficult as some of the tougher NES games. I still haven't beaten the game yet after 13hrs of trying to reach the Nuclear Throne, the last level is insane. If you don't have enough ammo or the right mutation you are screwed. I've gotten to the last level maybe 20x but on my last playthrough I only had a few more enemies to kill when a big green blob sat on my face. RUFKINKIDDIGNME!! I have 13hrs logged on a 15 minute game. I thought I was good at games, this game thinks otherwise. 3/22/15 - The day after I posted my review there were some balance changes and I was finally able to reach the Nuclear Throne. I like how impossible this was as it reminded me of old NES games but I think the balance changes were necessary. If you want to ramp up the difficulty you can add modifiers to your game by going through portals or play weaker characters.3/28/15 - The Throne is dead, long live the Nuclear Throne

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								There is that thing you get in a few games, that visceral feedback, that sense of truly having an impact on things around you. First time I can remember that feeling was in Dark Messiah, after kicking my first orc. Very few games really get that. Vlambeer, whatever their secret sauce is, GETS it.Now add the short time it takes to play a game, the multiple characters (even though I only ever play a few), the vast arsenal (far better than Borderlands : each weapon actually changes the way you play the game) and you've got something that would have been the bane of many a family back in the arcade days. The graphics are mostly meh, although imbued with a certain charm, without a doubt.It's also got that proper "what if I try _that_ combo of powers/weapons" that good roguelike have. But on acid. That "let me just try one more time" addiction that will turn a minutes long game into dozens of hours of gameplay...Just look at my record! And I haven't even beaten the game, yet!And I don't mind, I'm having too much fun anyway!Now, let me just get one more game...

												Please stay away from this game. It will take over your life. I've sunk 67 hours into this thing and I've only now looped it ONCE. It's really ♥♥♥♥ing hard, and it will completely win you over with its superb soundtrack, INCREDIBLE sound design, colourful cast of characters and that signature Vlambeer screenshake. The guns have an incredibly satisfying punch to them, you'll never get tired of shooting them. And you'll be doing a whole lot of shooting. If you enjoy dying over and over and over and shooting a whole lot of guns, then maybe the game is for you! You'll die a lot though! Dying means restarting the whole thing! But I mean if you have the patience for dying and restarting, there's a whole lot to do in the game. Like incredible amounts of things to discover and unlock. Fun things! Cool things! Very silly things! Secret endings! Daily and weekly challenges! Leaderboards!And a lot of dying!Don't say I didn't warn you!Great game, would die again 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5
												Judging my my 280 hours of play time, I think you can tell how much I like Nuclear Throne.Out of the hundreds of games I've played in my life, few have the same level of polish and fun that this game has.Everything on offer here is amazing, the character designs are colorful and creative, the guns are diverse and all of them are useful in some way (minus the flamethrower, that gun is completely worthless.) and the gunplay is above and beyond anything I could have expected, it's so good that you can dodge hundreds of fast projectiles while gunning down dozens of enemies if your skilled enough, and most deaths feel like they're your fault. Movement is spectacular, I never feel like I'm too clunky or too fast. Characters offer surprisingly diverse playstyles, each one has a unique personality and feel. The music, while not anything I would listen too outside of the game, is still serviceable, and fits right into the post-apocalyptic universe. This honestly applies to just me and possibly a few others, but the ability to, "Loop" makes this game for me. Being able to never really beat the game is great, and I always manage to make it a little farther each time I play, which elevates replay value through the roof.My only problems with this game has to be with how squishy your character is, and while not a problem at all in the normal game, by Loop 2 it boils down to dumb luck as to whether or not you get hit by one of the one hit kill enemies, or whether or not you run into a bad spawn. The insta-kill enemies in loop really make some deaths not your fault, since you can spawn right on yop of them from time to time. The 30fps frame lock is annoying, but the engine that Vlambeer used doesnt't allow 60fps anyway, so I can't really complain.Overall, an amazing game, provided me with over 200 hours of fun. Worthy of it's 12 dollar price tag, I don't think you need to wait for a sale.

content:
19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fast, chaotic, difficult, and absolutely addictive roguelike. It’s like Hotline Miami’s gameplay combined with Spelunky’s sensibilities. Don't be put off by the "early access" label, Nuclear Throne is already a very polished game. It’s full of interesting characters, upgrades, weapons, areas, and secrets. The controls are perfectly tight. The soundtrack is brilliant all the way through. The devs are enthusiastic about their work and it shows in terms of the game's level of detail, weekly updates, and their engagement with the community.It's not even complete and it's already one of my favorite games ever. There's no reason to wait, this is a must-buy for anyone who enjoys good fast-paced action.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Extremely fast-paced shooter where you have to keep track of everything going on and brace yourself for bullet hell.You play as one of 10 characters (more are being added), all with different abilities. The range of abilities paired with the different weapons and player mutations enables you to try many different playstyles until you find one that suits you.Some of the characters have melee weapons other have ranged weapons, all with different properties.Most of the gameplay is running around quickly in a small arena trying to kill all the enemies in order to get power-ups, ammunition & new weapons. Between the randomly generated levels your character gains mutations which are different perks applied to your character.

content:
y 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								(Review is based on Update # 59)Fast paced twitch shooter combined with a rogue-like. Very challenging game with most deaths can happen before you realize what is going on but a single run shouldn't take more than an hour. Developers are constantly updating the game which is great and despite being in early access, the foundation is really good.The only problems are that the game doesn't have that progression or replayability of another action/rogue-like game: The Binding of Issac. Despite procedurally generated levels, there isn't enough difference between runs to make them stand out in terms of new enemies, situations etc. But what's in the game so far is good and it can only get better from here.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 3, 2016
												You know that game you saw at the arcade that had all of those flashy lights and drew you in the second you saw it?  Remember how you then went up to it and put your quarter into it, and then before you even knew it, you got a game over screen?  And then instead of walking away, you put another quarter in the game to give it figure out what even happened, only for you to just barely grasp the gameplay before you died again?  And then you dumped your entire wallet into the game and by the end of it all, the longest you lasted was 10 minutes?Nuclear Throne is that arcade game.It proclaims itself to be a roguelike, similar to Binding of Isaac.  In fact, a lot of people make comparisons between the two games, saying that they're similar.  To that I say, there's actually not very in much in common.  While they are both roguelikes and you need to get to go through a number of levels to reach the "end", as well as having the same movement scheme with the WASD keys, and having a variety of characters to play as, those are the only similarities they have.One of the ways Nuclear Throne makes itself very different from Binding of Isaac is by making your primary means of attack with guns and melee weapons like wrenches and sledgehammers.  You use your curser to aim, and then you click whenever you want to hit/fire from your gun.  And as with real life guns, you need to reload and get more ammo after you've shot them all into your enemies' corpses.  The ammo is relatively easy to find, whether it's in chests or from drops after you kill enemies, but it's still a good idea to not unload all of your bullets at once, because some enemy will pop up when you need your bullets the most, and you WILL die.Another thing about Nuclear Throne is that each level has no doors.  It's one solid room of different environments depending on where you are, meaning that your enemies will find out eventually if you don't hide behind some walls.  In order to progress to the next level you have to kill everyone on the current level, but levels are so small in general, it should take you not even 5 minutes to make a corpse out of everyone.And finally, this game has a very arcade-like feel to it.  A single run can be done in 15 minutes, but just like all of those arcade games you might have tried to play, you will die.  You will die A LOT.  Enemies hit with a lot of power in this game, and if you're not quick, you'll get hit rather easily and blow up within 3 seconds.  Othertimes you'll get bombarded with ten enemies on the screen at once while you're also surrounded by tons of explosives.  Or even worse, you'll kill an enemy, and it'll explode, catching you in the blast and killing you that way.  The point is, you will shot full of holes all the time.  Success is not easily come by in this game.And yet despite this, this game is extremely addicting.  The very short amount of time it takes you to get to the Nuclear Throne, along with the fast-paced action, makes it very easy to get sucked in for hours and hours.  That mentality of "just one more try..." will consume you.  Maybe you won't get drawn into it as much as the Binding of Isaac games due to less content, but the addiction factor is still there.With that said, I can only reccomend this game to those who aren't afraid of a challenge.  You will die a lot, as I have reiterated many times in this review.  You will die because of stupid decisions, because you didn't move fast enough, or because the game decides it hates you and has hordes of rats storm you from both ends of a narrow hallway and sink their fangs into you.  This game does not care about you winning.  I'm pretty sure some of the Steam achievements make this apparent with how one of them requires you to sit upon the throne with a certain character when they're seconds away from death.  But if you don't mind that (and are perhaps a masochist), then by all means buy the game.  Just don't go expecting this to be Binding of Isaac, because you'll be in for quite a surprise then.

content:
y 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though I've only played like an hour and a half so far, Nuclear Throne is a fun, fast-paced, fun shooter that goes on and on and on until you've reached, the Nuclear Throne. There are a few different characters to use, each having different perks. There's many different guns, each using ammo that you have to pick up. The game goes on to the next level after you kill all the enemies, and if you die, you restart from level 1 or pick a new character. Like I said before, it's a fast-paced, fun shooter that you'll enjoy for a while, even if it's just constant levels. (Also, beware that ESC on your keyboard exits you out of your game when at the main screen!) Plus, the game is only $13, if you're looking for a cheap, but fun game. I'd give this game an 8.8/10

content:
y 7, 2016
												So this game plays a lot like both Hotline Miami and Binding of Isaac. First off you start as a measly level 1 mutant with a revolver, a special ability, and a thirst for plutonium and more power. The levels, loot, and enemies are all randomly generated, with set bosses at certain points. Get enough plutonium and you'll level up and get to pick one of four random new mutations (more ammo capacity, more melee range, some kills generate HP, and so on). When you die, it's game over. You will die a lot, and you will keep saying to yourself "Just one more time......" over and over again.

Early Access Review
								This game is so much dumb fun, and probably the best thing to come from Early Access. The characters are memorable, differing, and fun (my favorites are Crystal, Chicken, and Rogue). The game is in the most unique post-apocalyptic setting I've seen, being a grim nuclear wasteland that is also strangely cute and silly. The bosses are big and threatening. You'll want to press on even though it is a roguelike so you'll be starting over a lot. If you like roguelikes or just dumb fun, play Nuclear Throne. You won't regret it.

												10/10There is nothing I can say about this game that you can't already find in the countless positive reviews you'll find on this page. The gameplay is responsive and consistently engaging. I haven't even made it all the way through and I love it. The furthest I've reached is 5-3 and I died almost instantly on my first encounter with Lil Hunter. I was devastated that I died. I was overjoyed to have made it that far. I was excited to try again. And that's the best part about this game. No matter how much it kills you, no matter how frustrating it becomes, you never feel like it's impossible. It inspires you to try again and develop better skills. Now, THAT's what makes a great game. I did not reach the nuclear throne, but at least fish can roll, right?

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								**PLEASE KEEP IN MIND THIS WAS WRITTEN 10/26/13 AND AS THIS GAME IS IN BETA IT IS CONSTANTLY CHANGING SO THIS REVIEW IS BASED ON THE GAME AS IT WAS AT THE TIME**Yet another addicting roguelike from Vlambeer and friends, Nuclear Throne is the cooler older brother of Super Crate Box. This time around there are more crazy monsters to kill with another massive arsenal and seven new playable characters to do it with. When I first saw previews for the game, I recognized the work immediately as Vlambeer, as I was a huge fan of Super Crate Box. One of the most enjoyable aspects of this game is being able to move freely through an open level, opposed to the single screen of SCB as well as the option to choose from multiple characters with different stats and special abilities.After a few failed attempts at trying to reach out to Vlambeer via Twitter for a possible copy to review I just decided to buy it. Supporting indie developers like Vlambeer who have provided us gamers with awesome free games like Super Crate Box doesn’t bother me, I just didn’t want to wait till my next payday to be able to play this game, AND coincidentally Nuclear Throne happened to come out on my birthday. Anyway, I digress… Nuclear Throne is more fun than playing Mario 3 christmas morning 1988 and manages to keep you on your toes while you battle through each level where your goal is to clear it of all enemies. Loaded with upgrades, tons of different weapons and ammo, a boat load of monsters that came off a zombie infected Noah’s Ark of doom, and a cast of characters resembling the Garbage Pail Kids, Nuclear Throne is sure to turn you into the next Toxic Avenger.Nuclear Throne is Vlambeers latest action roguelike-like about mutants fighting their way through a post-apocalyptic world. The radioactive waste in the world allows mutants to get ahead by mutating new limbs on the fly, the abundant availability of powerful weaponry makes the quest to become ruler of the Wasteland one fraught with peril. At this point in development, Nuclear Throne consists of 7 playable characters and has 4 worlds, each containing 3 sub levels that you must complete before moving on to the next. Your ultimate goal is to clear the map, collect ammo, build your arsenal and gather nuclear waste to gain levels.To gain levels you must collect the nuclear waste capsules that enemies drop after you kill them. After collecting so many of these you gain your next level and given the opportunity to upgrade your character. Some of these upgrades include “Lucky Shot” that when added allows some shots to regenerate ammo. “Blood Lust” gives you the ability where some kills may regenerate your HP, or “Rhino Skin” which gives you an added +4HP. These upgrades are essential to your gameplay, and if you choose wisely you can get further and further every time you play.The gameplay of Nuclear Throne is genius and compelling, keeping you glued to your computer making every last bullet a battle cry at redemption. Each character has its own special ability and varied stats, for example, “Fish” gets more ammo than most other characters, and his special ability is the doge roll. Whereas “Crystal” gets more HP, and has the crystal shield as a special ability. Right now my favorite character is “Plant.” He moves around faster, and has the ability to throw seeds out and snare enemies making it easier to kill them. This helps greatly when trying to move around enemies that are shooting at you as well, not to mention snaring larger enemies allowing for an easier target to move around.Weaponry isn’t an issue when it comes to Nuclear Throne. Everything from a screwdriver to a grenade launcher, Vlambeer certainly didn’t leave anything out of this one. The shooting dynamics when using a mouse and keyboard are flawless, and put the power from your current weapon at your finger tips. Extra ammunition is found from killing enemies and dropped randomly, usually when you’re running low. Like many roguelikes, ammo is essential and there usually isn’t that much of it readily available, especially when using the triple machine gun.You can also find ammo and extra weapons from the chests scattered throughout each level, and health is also dropped this way as well.The music in Nuclear Throne blends perfectly with gameplay and isn’t overly annoying like in most other games. I liked that each level had its own unique and distinct music that was congruent to its surroundings. Graphicly, Nuclear Throne is a step up from Super Crate Box and adds more shading while adding more characteristics to the enemies and playable characters. Overall, Nuclear Throne is an awesome game, tons of fun to play, and leaves you wanting more. Anytime that I find myself thinking about a video game outside of my house I know that its a hit. Needless to say this game is incredible, and even in early development shows promise. I highly suggest this one, its bound to be another classic.Graphics: 7/10Playability: 7/10Story: 3/10Challenge: 7/10Replay Value: 7/10

content:
er 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								What is Nuclear Throne?------------------------------------A hectic bullet-hell battle to reach the fabled "Nuclear Throne." Fight through levels of deadly enemies that can and will kill you on sight. Shoot maggots with a Triple Machine-gun or use a crossbow on a bandit while avoiding hundreds of bullets that will chunk your health down pretty quickly.The cast of characters is vast and their abilities add a new type of playstyle everytime you try them out. Playing "Melting" lets you explode every corpse you create, but you only get 2 health. That's basically a one-hit wonder. Play as "Crystal" and block and reflect every shot for a limited time, but be careful not to get surrounded. Play as "Steroids" and get a hefty amount of health and dual-weilding capacity. Ever wanted to shoot double laser guns? I know I have.This game will keep you entertained and hitting R to quick restart for a good amount of time every session. The levels are randomly generated, and so are the enemies, but the difficulty never goes down. Gather experience to gain upgrades such as an increase in melee range or regenerating bullets on hit.If you manage to reach the Vault, you can gain a Crown upgrade that may make the game more rewarding, but also challenging. You could also choose no crown, for a bald head is the best head.Whether you're a casual gamer or a bullet hell lover, this game will manage to keep you entertained for it's value, not to mention Vlambeer likes to release constant updates fixing bugs and adding content.Testimonies-----------------"Pls good, such buy, wow." - Me"This game...is a game." - Me"Dude, shut up, these aren't testimonies." - Some guy"He payed me to write this." - Anonymous tip

content:
er 29, 2015
rating: worth buying at full pricescore: 8/10 - very good similar games: Doom, Binding of Isaactags: shooter, rogue-lite, top downNuclear Throne is one of those games which have great core gameplay, but lack content and maybe a bit polish too. Because of that the game didn't provide a satisfying experience to me although the gunplay is really satisfying. What I basicly expect from every rogue-lite game these days is the following: lots and lots of unlockables -> encourages multiple playthroughs and makes death not feel meaninglessThe only unlocks in Nuclear Throne are new characters, but those I would normally count as a bonus, since they don't affect your next playthrough at all, they just offer a new playstyle, but if you don't like most of the characters then these unlocks are worthless to you. And that was the case a bit for me in Nuclear Throne. Some of the characters are useless if you ask me, but the most fun to play character was definitly Steroids, and I just play as him. He has the highest DPS and is just the most crazy character which makes him by far the most fun to play for me. But at least the character design is really creative and cool. You can also unlock crowns but they are useless and don't have a big impact on the game, and you can unlock golden weapons which replace your starting weapon, which isn't a big deal, because you get new and good weapons really fast anyway.lots of different upgrades -> makes every run feel more uniqueThere are only a handful of upgrades (mutations are they called) in this game and a third of those are completely useless. Because of that your character build will be same more of less for every run. Also there is a mutation which heals you when you make kills, this is BY FAR the best mutation in the game and has a too big impact on the game. This wouldn't be a problem if the HP drops weren't so random. In some runs the game is generous and gives you lots of HP drops, in other runs you will rarely see one. What is the point in this extreme randomness?randomly generated levels need things which are worth randomly generating -> make every run feel more uniqueWhat I mean by this is how similar the runs feel because of how the levels are generated. The enemies you encounter for every region will be the same, the types of weapons you will find will be same, just the paths you have to go will be a bit different but the difference won't have any impact on how you will play the levels, they are just different so the game isn't completely the same every time. But this is not enough. In very few instances sometimes a rare enemy appeared in a level. This game needs more of that, don't have a set ensemble of enemy types per region and use them all, but have a big pool of enemies per region and only use a few of that pool, so you will encounter different enemies every run. The weapon drops could also use more variety. Maybe give weapons status effects like burn of freeze damage (that exists in the game but just a bit).the game needs to become harder after every playthrough -> encourage multiple playthroughs and allows the developers to better balance the learning and difficulty curveWhat I mean by this is how Binding of Isaac does things. For your first run there are only like 6 regions, when you beat the final boss you permanently unlock a new region after the final one for your next run which is more difficult. Then you unlock another region maybe, but then after beating the main boss 10 times the whole game gets more difficult, but that also makes sense because by this point you have unlocked tons of items and upgrades. Nuclear Throne has the "looping" mechanic and hard mode, but that's it.Another thing which is extremely infuriating in this game is how sometimes you can be nothing but unlucky and just die, especially in 5-3 where you sometimes spawn in the middle of million enemies while a boss appears which shoots 100 projectiles, flys all over the places while making explosions when landing, spawning more enemies AND when you beat him he will randomly fly in a direction and explode. You beat the boss but because RNG decided to make him fly in your direction and explode you loose anyway. There are lots of really cheap deaths like that in the game. Even more infuriating is when a portal spawns near a car and make the car explode which can kill you even if you have lots of HP. And the thing is I don't understand why this is, because apart from these cheap things the enemy design is GREAT with a lot of variety and depth.One last thing. The game's core gameplay is already really good and has depth, but it could have even more depth by allowing the player to carry more than 2 weapons. I think it would be great if you just could carry a weapon of each weapon type at the same time. This is would give the game more depth because then you would have to consider more criteria when making more decisions. Obviously enemy design and balance and other things have to be adjusted as well for this to work. Just think Doom and Serious Sam.The game still gets a REALLY good score from me, because the core gameplay is just really good, great character design, great enemy design, great weapon design, great sound design and great soundtrack. All the ingredients for a 10/10 game are there, but there is just not enough AT ALL around that. The game "Downwell" has the same problem, but that game costs 3€.Oh, also: 30 fps lock is ♥♥♥♥ing stupid especially for this type of game.

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												Whenever I look at reviews for games, I always look at how long the individual has played before I read the review.  I wish Steam had an option to sort negative and positive reviews by playtime.  Some people are quick to judge negatively or positively before seeing what a game really has to offer.  Have you ever met someone that you liked initially, but upon getting to know further didn't like so much?  People that have spent more time on a game are better suited to fairly judge it.Nuclear Throne isn't quite like any game I've played before.  It's a stage based twin-stick shooter with high levels of randomization.  You play as one of many mutants trying to make it to the Nuclear Throne.  Why?  It's never really stated.  The game doesn't have an in game story line.  You can go out on the web and search for information that the developers commented about if you like, but in game there isn't very much to go on at all.  Ultimately this doesn't matter much, as most people probably aren't playing this sort of game for the story.As you play through each stage and make your way to the Nuclear Throne you gain experience, level up, and find weapons.  Every time you level up, you select a mutation (upgrade) from a random list up until the final level where you get to select an ultra mutation which is unique to the mutant you are using.  Each mutant has a special ability and the vast majority of them are useful in one way or another.  You can eventually unlock different/slightly enhanced starting weapons for the mutants. It is also possible to unlock crowns for each character, each crown makes various gameplay changes.  It's a neat idea, but unfortunately many of the crowns are outright bad to the point of being detrimental.The individual stages are very short, and randomly generated.  This is both positive and negative respectively.  The short stages enable very fast games.  You can reach the throne in less than 10 minutes if you are going at a good pace.  The randomly generated stages give the game a high level of replayability but also end up being its greatest flaw. Games with randomly generated levels often do so by having a large number of premade segments and attaching a handful of them together to create the level.  This doesn't seem to be the case in Nuclear Throne, and the end result is inconsistent stages with almost no level design.  You can start a stage in a great location, and the next run you could start the same stage in a completely awful location.  After playing for a while you will have an idea of which stages are particularly egregious offenders of this and be mentally prepared for what might await, but in the end it may or may not work out depending on what you encounter.  One other issue with the stages is that they feature a very low number of unique enemies.  The three ice levels, for example, have four enemies: tanks, snowbots, robot wolves, and snow bandits.  This might not sound bad but the game crams so many of the same enemy on the screen that it evokes thoughts of an mspaint picture where a five year old learned how to use copy and paste for the first time.  The aforementioned issues become especially apparent when you loop the game.  I'll give fair warning here and say that I don't like looping as a feature in games, and I know it's something many players appreciate. When you loop everything hits the fan, and it's ugly.  The game abandons the modicum of level design that was present and flings stages absolutely filled with enemies at you.  This pours the coolness of weapon variety and mutation selection down the drain.  The farther you go, you'll discover that some mutations are extremely important, and that a small number of weapons are actually viable so late in the game.The graphics are mostly unimpressive. I wouldn't describe them as good or bad, but I will say that I didn't find them to be very pretty.  I did think that the fact that characters don't turn to face the direction they're moving in was an odd choice.  The soundtrack is great and each song fits its stage well.  The music choices in the sewer, palace, and throne room were notably good.Nuclear Throne has many flaws, but it is also a lot of fun at times.  The action is fast paced and the runs can be short enough that people without a lot of free time to spend playing can have a quick run between other activities.  For anyone on the fence about buying this game, I suggest you search Google for Wasteland Kings.  It is the original prototype for Nuclear Throne and similar enough that it should give you an idea of whether or not the game is for you.  One warning though: I don't believe Wasteland Kings has gamepad support and the full release of Nuclear Throne does, so don't let that affect your opinion.  I feel that with a handful of changes and a small amount of polish this game could be something truly remarkable, but as it is I cannot recommend it at the current price of $11.99.

content:
y 6, 2016
												I tend to repel against indie titles because most have pixelated graphics, a style I never quite enjoyed looking at. So after I finally lowered my biased opinion for once I saw a game called nuclear throne. Intrigued by it's similar gameplay like "The binding of isaac" which I enjoyed quite a bit, I bought the game after countless hesitations and started it up the moment it was done downloading.Man was this a breath of fresh air. This game to me was like Jesus freaking christ showing up to christian people. I never thought I would say "This is harder than trying to sing the russian national anthem backwards without even having heard it nor the russian language once" but here I am. If you're a fan of any rouge-like games whatsoever, then this game will certainly fulfill your dreams and beyond.   The gameplay is fast, hard it will probably end pretty quick (Like me in bed) because you died but you will want to start over again because it's so addictive.  The enemies will tear you apart, Your weapons will most likely screw you over in one way or another and if that's not enough the bosses will surely leave a scar on your back saying "i was here you lil shet."The music is bloody brilliant and fills you with adrenaline, actually helping you getting through the harsh level. Even there is little to no story to be discovered in the game there are bits and pieces which the player can make his/her/it's own conclusion to what the story is about.I think this game is great. Actually no, scratch that. I think this game sets the bar for how a difficult but fair game should be. Not a complete pounding session but a pounding session with some lube. And maybe some baby powder.Also fish can roll.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
19, 2016
												Jesus ♥♥♥♥ where to begin...Nuclear throne is one of those games where you WILL have a love/hate relationship.Love it for its characters, setting, fantastic soundtrack, bosses and butt-ton of weapons,and hate it for its brutal difficulty and the occasional area where good runs go to die (im looking at you crystal caves).So, lets get into it shall we?Nuclear throne is a roguelike shooter set in a post-apocalyptic world filled with mutants, freaks and everything inbetween. You play as a rhag-tag band of mutants, all filled with character and personality. These mutants dream of placing their mutant butts on the nuclear throne, a myth thats believed by these guys. These mutants are special, because as soon as they die, they get teleported back by these mystical portals popping up across the wasteland.The story is simple, you choose a mutant, and you travel across the many lands filled with a variety of freaks, bandits and  floating ♥♥♥♥ing crystals. In every main area (Badlands, scrapyard Etc) you'll encounter a boss that you must slay in order to go to the sub areas (Not the official name, but something I call them). These are areas that are inbetween the ordinary, 3 level areas. These are 1 level areas that are completely different in setting to other areas and hold special enemies and loot.After doing all of this (Trust me, its a long task) and doing specific things related to things I cant say due to spoilers, you can loop. This means going aaaaaall the way back to the start, but this time its harder, much, much harder. The enemies are tougher and theres a whole new cast of bosses to slay, each one harder than the last. The loot is better, but the risk is bigger.The way collectibles go, there are B-skins for every playable mutant, unlockable by doing specific things, some hard, some are very easy. There are also crowns to unlock through playing, this is essentially run modifiers that you can aquire mid way through the run or at the beginning. They add an extra challenge for the seasoned veteran. There are also golden guns that replace some of the original guns. These special versions are found in a certain area(s) and increase certain stats of the weapon or doing specific things. Also, it shines ingame and can replace the starting pistol if you finish the area its found in.The soundtrack is one of the best ive heard ever. And ive played quite a few games in my time. Each boss has its own song to go in the backround and each area has its own song too. Its so good that I listen to the songs in my spare time.So, to break it down, heres a simpler form of what I just said for the challenged reader:Pros:Fantastic sountrackVibrant characters (That talk in their own made up language)Simple yet enjoyable storyinteresting lore (read that ♥♥♥♥, its brilliant)colourful and marvelously designed areasbeautiful character and enemy designA lot of variety in enemy types and looksBosses are amazing yet challenging if not preparedBrutally hard- Keeps you on your toes at all times, even if you are just fighting a few banditsArtwork is brilliantDevs that listen to the community and are gamers themselvesCons:Some areas are more unbalanced than others (Crystal caves again...)Bugs are uncommon, but come in small sizesOften times you wonder "What the hell just killed me"Thank you for reading, this game is my favorite roguelike, and I love it, even though my hours say otherwise.Would I reccommend this game? Without a doubt. Are there things that could be improved? Of course, but every game is like that. Its 8.99 for endless fun, anger and stupidity with the amount of loot, weapons and collectables to be collected.Thank you again for reading.

content:
26, 2016
												This game will require much from you. It will not relent, it will not hold your hand. Yet for the noble warrior who can tame its maddening trials, great glory awaits. This game brings me back to my early gaming days, playing Ghouls'n Ghosts (SNES) over and over without a save file and enduring through hours of restarts and near misses. Complete with an authentic old- school graphics style and tough but fair difficulty curve, it is pretty much the ultimate modern- day arcade shooter. Unlike the low- res games of yore, however, Nuclear Throne has randomly generated levels, randomly dropping weapons and randomly selected skills to enjoy along your journey. This is a game of skill, strategy, and white- knuckle reflexes. And pain. Lots and lots of pain.Vlambeer, you've done it again.

er 29, 2015
												Nuclear Throne is one of the most spectacular games I've ever played.The game itself is satisfying, fun, atmospheric, and ever 150 hours in, I keep finding things I've never seen before. It requires skill, but also integrates an element of randomness, and you could play this game thousands of times and it would never get old.There is extreme variety, so that the game never seems repetitive. As you progress through each run, your character develops a playstyle of his/her own, based off of their respective mutations and weapons.This game has provided me with some harrowing and awesome moments, many of which kill me, but the few I get past give me an extreme sense of gratification.It is also one of the few games I actually enjoy watching someone else play.I would reccomend this game to pretty much anyone.

content:
y 6, 2016
												I tend to repel against indie titles because most have pixelated graphics, a style I never quite enjoyed looking at. So after I finally lowered my biased opinion for once I saw a game called nuclear throne. Intrigued by it's similar gameplay like "The binding of isaac" which I enjoyed quite a bit, I bought the game after countless hesitations and started it up the moment it was done downloading.Man was this a breath of fresh air. This game to me was like Jesus freaking christ showing up to christian people. I never thought I would say "This is harder than trying to sing the russian national anthem backwards without even having heard it nor the russian language once" but here I am. If you're a fan of any rouge-like games whatsoever, then this game will certainly fulfill your dreams and beyond.   The gameplay is fast, hard it will probably end pretty quick (Like me in bed) because you died but you will want to start over again because it's so addictive.  The enemies will tear you apart, Your weapons will most likely screw you over in one way or another and if that's not enough the bosses will surely leave a scar on your back saying "i was here you lil shet."The music is bloody brilliant and fills you with adrenaline, actually helping you getting through the harsh level. Even there is little to no story to be discovered in the game there are bits and pieces which the player can make his/her/it's own conclusion to what the story is about.I think this game is great. Actually no, scratch that. I think this game sets the bar for how a difficult but fair game should be. Not a complete pounding session but a pounding session with some lube. And maybe some baby powder.Also fish can roll.

er 29, 2015
												Nuclear Throne is one of the most spectacular games I've ever played.The game itself is satisfying, fun, atmospheric, and ever 150 hours in, I keep finding things I've never seen before. It requires skill, but also integrates an element of randomness, and you could play this game thousands of times and it would never get old.There is extreme variety, so that the game never seems repetitive. As you progress through each run, your character develops a playstyle of his/her own, based off of their respective mutations and weapons.This game has provided me with some harrowing and awesome moments, many of which kill me, but the few I get past give me an extreme sense of gratification.It is also one of the few games I actually enjoy watching someone else play.I would reccomend this game to pretty much anyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 16, 2016
												This is the kind of rougelike I've been waiting for for a LONG time. And it's pretty ♥♥♥♥in' good.It's a fast-paced, skill-based shmup rougelike where you shoot enemies and collect items in randomly generated levels.  You're challenged to dodge projectiles, mind your ammo, use special abilities and strategically choose from a wide array of weapons and upgrades for the most optimal runs. Like most rougelikes, it's brutally hard, but what I think separates this rougelike from most of the others is its attention to balance and its surprising level of fairness. Most if not all items and characters the game offers are great for their own reasons, but more importantly, bad situations can always be turned around if you think fast; nearly every death I've ever had occurred because I was careless, didn't watch my back, or I miscalculated while dodging hellfire. There are virtually no instant kills in this game, and cheap shots just don't exist. That being said, you can expect your HP to get whittled down very quickly if you're not careful, so don't get cocky!The unlockable characters cover every character archetype under the sun (speedster, tank, glass cannon, crowd control, dual wielder, berserker, etc.), and they all play quite differently thanks to having dramatically different special abilities... the farther you get into the game, the more compelling each unlockable gets. Coupled with the weapons and upgrades (called "mutations") upon levelling up, this allows for a multitude of different ways to experience the game. The levels themselves are also quite varied and full of secrets.And if you want to do something a little less random, the game offers Daily and Weekly seed challenges. The Daily seed locks the map generation and mutations, and you're challenged to play through it once to achieve a high score on daily leaderboards. Weekly seeds are available Friday through Sunday and can be played through multiple times, but you're locked into a character, a special weapon and one of twelve game-modifying "crowns".Aesthetically and soundwise, the game is oozing with style. Environments and characters are vibrant, cartoony, well-animated and original, taking full advantage of the pixel aesthetic. The rock-oriented soundtrack is upbeat and atmospheric, followed by background sound effects for added ambience. There's no "dialogue" per se, but many of the ingame characters add spice to the atmosphere through unintelligable quips and one liners spoken in an alien language.If you like a challenge, random levels, and fast paced shootemup action, get this game. Like, I wouldn't even wait for a sale, it's just good.

The next update comes out and its fixed but something else is broke... but thats fine. It runs and you can play it thats all that matters. Honestly Nuclear Throne would be a 10/10 but that one problem that comes up gives it a solid                                                                                       9/10 get this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 9, 2016
-----------NUCLEAR THRONE-----------Out of nowhere, I see that a bulk of my friends have this weird new game already in their library that seemed to have just been released, it has "Overwhelmingly Postive" reviews on Steam, and so it popped up on my radar. Did a little searchin' and saw a trailer or two, checked out some reviews/gameplay. And then during the Winter Sale recently while prices were a little different (not NT however, that remained $11.99) I was looking on the SteamGameSwap subreddit and saw someone was trading "[Have] NUCLEAR THRONE [Want] Darkest Dungeon", then I saw another one that said "[H] Darkest Dungeon [W] Jotun", which I had to trade. So thankfully, I was able to swap my extra Jotun (good game, recommend it) for their Darkest Dungeon (never sparked any interest but it seems to be liked), and so that's when I traded Darkest Dungeon for NUCLEAR f****** THRONE!!! (Cool story, ehh bros?) And boy oh boy, am I glad I made that trade! NUCLEAR THRONE, It's fun, it's replayable, exciting, has an irreverent aesthetic, simple refreshingly minimalized controls, intuitive game mechanics. It has rogue-y elements with some of the various passive traits that get chosen along the way leveling up, there is a variety of weapons and enemies, and I have yet to get even CLOSE to the actual "Nuclear Throne" yet! So it taunts you to keep coming back, and keep trying again. The game is casual enough for anyone to try, but (happily) difficult enough that it takes some skills and experiences and hours to truly master. It's definitely one of those: --"*In game, doing well, then something overtakes you, you die* Awww F***! Ok ok, ONE MORE GAME!! *Get a little bit further but then die on a seemingly exponentially harder level, but you have a taste for it, so you need MORE* Dammit, HOW DID I GET HIT BY THAT!, OK, ok, ONE MORE TRY, this is the one!"-- Types of Games. If you enjoyed some of the recent platformers and arcade shooters who utilize that familiar-yet-fresh visual enviornment and ambience, and to be honest I hate this term, "throwback/retro-graphics" of days past with games like the outstanding 'Hotline Miami', in which fellow men and women of the 16-bit Generation were able to have their cake and eat it too with the graphical nostalgia and the exceptional music that adds texture and depth to that world they created. Of course, this is different, but similar in it's own unique execution. It would be fun to see a full multiplayer mod where players can deathmatch. But even without that, this game is entirely worth the $12 bucks. tl;dr Buy the game, it's great, replayable, postapocalyptic roguelike fun, and there's even cards & achievements!                                           -+===PUN2404===+-

content:
2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fast intense arcade-like action. The gameplay focuses on shooting, bullet hell-style dodging and short-term planning.Rounds are bite-sized and you can instantly retry after dying, but you'll likely take a few minutes to build concentration.Very polished for an early access game, and gets updated frequently. With different characters, secret unlockables and lots of mutations/skills, there's already a lot of content.Nuclear Throne is fairly hard - you easily get cornered and die very quickly.Due to smooth controls the game feels mostly fair, but there's some enemies and situations you can just do very little against.

content:
er 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you are worried by the Early Access tag, you shouldn't be. The devs regularly update the game and to be frank, if they never updated the game again I wouldn't be upset. You won't know you're playing an Early Access game.The random level generation keeps the game fresh and there are a good variety of characters. Each have their own...I dont want to use the word "powers" but thats just what i call them. Examples include a chicken that can slow down time and a fish that can roll around. The game gets pretty intense with all the bullets flying around and its even better with a friend. I have 40.2 hrs in as of this review and its only going higher. Completely reccommended. BUY IT NOW!

								This is one of a very very very small handful of games where i can play for 10 minutes and be immensely satisfied, because the pure play-by-play speed of Nuclear Throne ♥♥♥♥s you up on a vague cousin to adrenaline that only happens when you play a ludicrously over-the-top video game that pushes you to act immediately with zero sympathy for your failures. There is no good luck in Nuclear Throne, only bad luck, because a random generated map that'd be considered "good luck" is still a frenzied maze of bullets and action that you have to act on pure reflex to conquerAnd with more content coming out on a near-weekly basis? Hell yes I'm glad i payed full price+early access bonus to get this now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2015
Early Access Review
								As someone who played the original Wasteland Kings, finally being able to afford this game and play through it is like a dream come true. I'm completely awed at how far this game has come, and I could not be any more pleased with what I've played.You get dropped in a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland as a mutant with nothing but a revolver and a dream. And huge mobs of freaky ♥♥♥ creatures, robots, bandits, and everything else that you probably wouldn't want to encounter in a wasteland. All to get a piece of that sweet sweet throne.This game is an arcade style top down shoot 'em up, with different characters to pick from and randomized maps and guns, so no two runs are never the same. You will need to learn what works and what gets you killed faster than that assassin that you didn't see that just ran up behind you and ended your attempt. Now you know to stay on your toes. This game is unforgiving, and brutally unfair. But that's what makes it fun. There's no hand holding. It's all you.This game is being constantly updated, tweaked, and improved. It's already endless fun. Vlambeer has created one of the absolute best games on Steam. I would highly, HIGHLY, SO FREAKING HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who loves brutal, fast paced action, explosions, and that kind of motivating frustration that makes you say "Oh yeah? I'll show you, I'll beat this game next run!"

content:
y 5
												WARNING: This game can be very rage inducing. If you are expecting to find a Binding of Isaac/Enter the Gungeon be careful because this one is very different. Nuclear Throne is very fast paced and takes a good amount of reflexes. The diiferent characters, weapons and upgrades offer good variety of gameplay and a good amount of replayability. The art is great and the music also.But even when you start to get really good with the game, it will still mess you up. There are many cheap deaths in the game that will ruin a good run and will make you rage like hell. You can spawn in a bad place and have bullets coming from all sides, die from a car exploding from rebounding bullets or some enemy that will dodge your bullet in the last moment.The first few stages of the game are ok but after that the game has a huge difficulty spike. Many of the enemies you will encounter can kill you in a few hits and you will be dead before realizing.Overall, this is one of the best rogue-likes i have ever played and i highly recommend it but stay away if you get easily frustrated.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2016
												Be prepared to read the words "You did not reach the nuclear throne" a lot.  Be prepared to accidently kill yourself when your disk gun shot richocets off a wall and back at you.  Be prepared for an adrenaline rush every time you face Lil' Hunter.In this game, you will die a lot.  It's bullet hell and you have 8 measly hit points.  Seems like it's not a problem right? Well, most shots in the game will take down half that and more.  There's no invincibility frames after getting hit, some enemies shoot powerful enough weapons that they will kill you in one shot.And yet you keep playing.There's a beautiful feel to the game.  The gunfire sounds are audibly pleasing, Every hit on an enemy is satisfying.  As you progress further, the game only gets more fun.  After looping, you begin to feel unstoppable, but eventually you get claimed and the struggle continues.  You always die in this game, but you die a little less frequently as you progress.Do yourself a favor and pick this gem up.  You won't regret it.One small note, the developers have stopped working on the game, so if you see any bugs, it's unlikely you'll get a fix for it for a long time.

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a rougelike game where you play as one of 12 characters. Each character has their own special ability. Such as spawning in allies for the cost of health or having the ability to roll. Every time you level up, you get to choose 1 out of 4 upgrades. Once you level up to around level 5, it gets really fun. at around level 9, once you level up again, you get to choose your ultimate mutation. They are different ultimate mutations for each character so you might have to find out for yourself what each mutation does. (or look at the wiki) So it's really fun, many options for gameplay, and a lot of characters and weapons. Would I recommend it? Yeah.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
26, 2014
												UPDATED 1.0 REVIEW:First let us look back to my review on August 26th 2014!---Alpha based review: Just like their previous games Vlambeer hits the nail on it's head by once again giving the player INSTANT satisfaction, on easy to LEARN, but hard to MASTER gameplay. This all nicely shown in a pixel art style that representative, fun and appealling.---New review:First off: This is one of the best Early Acces game releases, probably the best. With their mentality to really get everything out of EA they went and did it. Every Tuesday and Thursday on of the team was streaming: showing new projects in the developent, streaming the game, having fun with new ideas, testing new features, answering questions. They have truelly been an inspiration for me in the past 1.5 years I have followed them develop this game. We were able to see it from beginning to end and we got delivered what they were promised.The Good:- The game play: it's fast and fun- Instant gratification: Jump right into the action, no bla bla. (If you get the joke, well done).Lot's of characters, weapons and MUTATIONS: so many combinations to try out, you keep combining and you have to, as everything is randomly found.- Good challenge: If you're not a very skilled player, this game is still fun, you will still have a feeling of achievement after ending a run. For the high skilled: try staying alive when you are looped! More bosses, more environments, harder enemies!- Audio: The reason I bought the game. The rough sounds gives a tough feel, a super attitude to a game that oozes with action. Every gun feels better.- Price: €12,99, that's not pricey for a single/co-op game.The Bad: - Crashes: Game crashes when immediately leaving the co-op menu, after entering.- Stats: Stats do not load.The Ugly:- Some graphic bugs: Shovel looks weird, sometimes a glitch.Conclusion:I highly recommend this game, if you like top down shooters, guns blazing, rough audio, a cool soundtrack and EXPLOSIONS! So much fun and hard to get through. You'll easily get you money out of it! Thanks JW + Rami (Vlambeer) and team.

content:
er 18, 2015
												Nuclear Throne is a fast paced shooter. I feel that it's a cross between a twin-stick shooter and The Binding of Isaac. It is a hard, but addicting game that rewards you the more time you spend honing your skills. Yes, some of your level spawns can ruin your run, but it's mostly player error. If you like a challenge, this game is for you. It's not Dark Souls difficult, but some days it can feel that way. I have logged many hours into the game, and yet to tire of it. I am gaining skill with each character, and what guns and mutations work best with them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2016
												Be prepared to read the words "You did not reach the nuclear throne" a lot.  Be prepared to accidently kill yourself when your disk gun shot richocets off a wall and back at you.  Be prepared for an adrenaline rush every time you face Lil' Hunter.In this game, you will die a lot.  It's bullet hell and you have 8 measly hit points.  Seems like it's not a problem right? Well, most shots in the game will take down half that and more.  There's no invincibility frames after getting hit, some enemies shoot powerful enough weapons that they will kill you in one shot.And yet you keep playing.There's a beautiful feel to the game.  The gunfire sounds are audibly pleasing, Every hit on an enemy is satisfying.  As you progress further, the game only gets more fun.  After looping, you begin to feel unstoppable, but eventually you get claimed and the struggle continues.  You always die in this game, but you die a little less frequently as you progress.Do yourself a favor and pick this gem up.  You won't regret it.One small note, the developers have stopped working on the game, so if you see any bugs, it's unlikely you'll get a fix for it for a long time.

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a rougelike game where you play as one of 12 characters. Each character has their own special ability. Such as spawning in allies for the cost of health or having the ability to roll. Every time you level up, you get to choose 1 out of 4 upgrades. Once you level up to around level 5, it gets really fun. at around level 9, once you level up again, you get to choose your ultimate mutation. They are different ultimate mutations for each character so you might have to find out for yourself what each mutation does. (or look at the wiki) So it's really fun, many options for gameplay, and a lot of characters and weapons. Would I recommend it? Yeah.

content:
9, 2015
Early Access Review
								You did not reach the Nuclear Throne.You shall see the above text hundreds, maybe thousands of times before getting past the first three zones.But the lure of the Throne is a Siren's Song you cannot ignore. Yes, your life is hard. Still, you must try.The Throne is all that keeps you going. Can you find it? Will anyone ever find it? No one has touched it since...But what of the world that used to be? There used to be trees here. The air was once clean, waters once clear.Your gruelling journey will only ever end with the sitting upon the Throne, if the Legends prove true. The only hope you can have true faith in now is the Throne. Somehow, deep down, you know.The Throne definitely exists.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a rogue-like twin-stick shooter. You play as one of the many characters and fight to claim your rite to sit on the nuclear throne. There are a lot of weapons, and the difficulty is very high. It's very fast-paced, and extremely enjoyable. The game is constantly being developed, which is really nice. It makes it so there are fresh things almost every week. One drawback is that unlocks (and settings) are reset whenever it updates, which is almost every week. Luckily most of the characters have really easy unlocks and take 1 run to get for the most part. Even if you're one of those people who is wary of early-access games, this game is at an extremely playable state, and even if the game was considered "finished" at this point i would still be very happy with it. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes rogue-likes.

content:
er 2, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of a very very very small handful of games where i can play for 10 minutes and be immensely satisfied, because the pure play-by-play speed of Nuclear Throne ♥♥♥♥s you up on a vague cousin to adrenaline that only happens when you play a ludicrously over-the-top video game that pushes you to act immediately with zero sympathy for your failures. There is no good luck in Nuclear Throne, only bad luck, because a random generated map that'd be considered "good luck" is still a frenzied maze of bullets and action that you have to act on pure reflex to conquerAnd with more content coming out on a near-weekly basis? Hell yes I'm glad i payed full price+early access bonus to get this now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is an insanely difficult and sometimes straight up unfair rouge-like.I still for some odd reason find it fun and interesting despite this.Pros:➤Wide range of different characters with varying abilities.➤Quite a lot of weapons.➤Plenty of different areas with varying looks and enemies, along with secrets.➤Original & interesting boss fights.➤Very high skill ceiling.➤Crown mechanic is weird but interesting and fun to play around with.➤Lots of Mutations to obtain to keep things interesting during playthroughs.➤Local CO-OP!Cons:➤Early game is quite boring, it takes a few areas to get hectic.➤The game mostly evolves around RNG. If you don't get good weapon/enemy spawns, or get bad Mutations, you're just screwed.➤Some deaths can be unfair due to being shot by something off-screen.➤As with the Crowns mechanic, some of them are just objectively bad and have no use in a playthrough.➤Some of the AI are just a tad dumb at times, enemies will get stuck on corners and such.➤Some weapons are just useless.Verdict:I like this game. It has a lot of problems, but I still find it to be quite fun.It's rage inducing and unfair, but that's what makes Nuclear Throne so.. Nuclear Throne.

content:
2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fast intense arcade-like action. The gameplay focuses on shooting, bullet hell-style dodging and short-term planning.Rounds are bite-sized and you can instantly retry after dying, but you'll likely take a few minutes to build concentration.Very polished for an early access game, and gets updated frequently. With different characters, secret unlockables and lots of mutations/skills, there's already a lot of content.Nuclear Throne is fairly hard - you easily get cornered and die very quickly.Due to smooth controls the game feels mostly fair, but there's some enemies and situations you can just do very little against.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Incredibly entertaining, every time I die I can't wait to start over and try again. Simple, playful and challenging game that is a lot of fun in single player, but even more so in local 2 player co-op. I play it with an X360 controller and at first it seemed like the controls would be slightly off, but you get used to them quickly and soon NUCLEAR THRONE will be your favourite game to grind! The randomly generated levels, weapon drops and leveling system makes it fun to play over and over again, trying different characters, different perks and weapons. The only complaints I have is the wonky "work in progress" options-menu and the lack of online multiplayer, but other than that this game is a really good time, I highly recommend checking it out if you are into these types of games!

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								After playing the game from when it first came around on Steam, I have to say this game is just awesome. While most people are driven away by the Early Access label, being in early access is what kept me playing this game more and more. When I first got it, it was a lot of fun. With every week that came, a new update came for the game. New content, fixes, balancing, and more. This is what kept me returning to it. Every week I would check if the new update came out, to see if they added a new area, new weapon, or sometimes even a new character. Overall, this game is fast paced and tons of fun. In some areas it can become a nightmare with all the bullets, but with each new update they are balancing certains aspects of the game to keep it a bit more fair. Every time you die, you can't really blame the game. All your mistakes are just because of you, and it can take a long time to get pretty good at the game.So, yeah, pretty awesome game.

content:
y 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fast, hectic and difficult. This top-down bullet-hell rouge-like, despite being in early access, has great depth of play, brilliant weapon and charecter selection and fantastic feeling of reward. Your play style will be constantly changing as you get farther and discover better and more over-powered cobinations of mutations and weapons (supposing you don't immedietly snap to the laser weapons.) And this game isn't afraid at all to rub how OP you can get right in your nose. Feel the power and steam roll the game before one cocky mistake lands you in the soup, and the game claims it all from you again, leaving you to sit and wonder at the campfire once more: will I ever reach the Nuclear Throne?

content:
8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is an indie rouguelike-ish game, but i would consider it a hack'n'slash game. Eventhough it's still in early access , the game seems complete, Vlambeer, the devs are updating the game every week.So, let's get right into the review!=======Story/Lore=======The story isn't the main focus of the game, it's pretty basic, but later compensated by the gameplay and graphics styleHere you have some of the story:Earth became a nuclear wasteland, after some time, humans and other organic organisms started mutating, they've grown stronger, with the hability to use guns and other stuff, the game's main objective is to reah the "Nuclear Throne"there's not much to it :S=======Gameplay=======Well, as i pinted out on the start, it's a fast paced rouguelike game where you have a variety of characters and weapons to choose, you go trhogh stages, defeat bosses, and do loops, it's a top-down shooter.=======Music=======The music amd sound effects for this game are simply amazing, composed by JUKIO KALLIO and JOONAS TURNER really stuned me, its great music, in my opinion it's way better than som AAA games out there.=======Art/Graphics=======All Vlambeer games have the same art style, nuclear throne isn't an exeption, the animations are smooth, the game looks beautiful.=======Final Veredict=======08/10It's a game defnitly worth buying. it's extremely funny!-xoxo Kyozumo, btw, if Vlambeer is reading this, i came from Mcswift101

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Easily one of my favorite games of all times. I'm a big fan of rogue-likes but, until now, I have not really been a big fan of bullet hell games. The game is exciting from the first second, the action is fast and chaotic, and the difficulty ramps up steadily. Each run can last anywhere from a couple of minutes to 30+ minutes. It takes seconds to randomly generate a new floor so it keeps you in the action and always keeps you guessing. The entire environment is destructable so using explosive weapons, destroying certain objects, or enemies can greatly change the landscape of a floor. That along with the corpses staying on the floor, by the end of the 3-4 minute long floor, it really looks like a huge battle had just occurred. On the surface, the characters may seem pretty similar considering most of them all start with the same weapon, have the same movement speed, have the same amount of HP, and can hold the same number of weapons. Once you spend a couple of hours with a character you realize how unique they actually are and how easily you can create some pretty unique character builds by applying new mutations. Mutations are earned after reaching a new character level and can greatly enhance or modify the single run you are on. Mutations range from higher max HP and max ammo, to modifying weapons, to more utility based like allowing you to break through walls. A ton of secrets, easter eggs, and unlocks are scattered throughout the game. Bosses are challenging and fun. Mini-bosses and stronger variations of common enemies tend to spawn periodically on certain floors to keep you on your toes. There are a TON of weapons to find in random drops and random chests. Each weapon is unique and has it's own pros and cons. This makes it more interesting and there are very few instances where one gun is a hands-down upgrade over another gun because a more powerful version may have a slower fire-rate or consume a lot more ammo. Nuclear Throne is addicting, exciting, super fast-paced, and amazing fun. I currently have over 200 hours on record and don't anticipate ending that anytime soon. Highly recommended to people who enjoy shooters, bullet hells, rogue-likes, and fast-paced games in general. 10/10

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. It's rare that I ever put as much time into a game as I have with this one, and I'm not even close to considering stopping yet. The combat is rarely an issue, and every level provides a new type of challenge to overcome. 12 different characters are featured, each with their own unique passive and active, and all offering a different play style. While some mutations may be better than others, it's impossible to go wrong with mutation choices as they all offer a worthwhile upgrade. All of this combined into an endless roguelike with countless different weapons makes for an amazing experience...If you're patient. The flip side to this game is that it is BRUTALLY difficult. To master this game, unless you're one of those people who's just amazing at video games, you will need time. A lot of it. You will die hundreds, if not thousands of times to mistakes you can't believe you made. I'm approaching 200 hours in this game and I still have rage-inducing deaths on the scrapyard in daily runs.All in all, buy this game! But do so knowing that it will be frustrating and time-consuming to master.

content:
4, 2015
Early Access Review
								As someone who played the original Wasteland Kings, finally being able to afford this game and play through it is like a dream come true. I'm completely awed at how far this game has come, and I could not be any more pleased with what I've played.You get dropped in a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland as a mutant with nothing but a revolver and a dream. And huge mobs of freaky ♥♥♥ creatures, robots, bandits, and everything else that you probably wouldn't want to encounter in a wasteland. All to get a piece of that sweet sweet throne.This game is an arcade style top down shoot 'em up, with different characters to pick from and randomized maps and guns, so no two runs are never the same. You will need to learn what works and what gets you killed faster than that assassin that you didn't see that just ran up behind you and ended your attempt. Now you know to stay on your toes. This game is unforgiving, and brutally unfair. But that's what makes it fun. There's no hand holding. It's all you.This game is being constantly updated, tweaked, and improved. It's already endless fun. Vlambeer has created one of the absolute best games on Steam. I would highly, HIGHLY, SO FREAKING HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who loves brutal, fast paced action, explosions, and that kind of motivating frustration that makes you say "Oh yeah? I'll show you, I'll beat this game next run!"

content:
26, 2014
												UPDATED 1.0 REVIEW:First let us look back to my review on August 26th 2014!---Alpha based review: Just like their previous games Vlambeer hits the nail on it's head by once again giving the player INSTANT satisfaction, on easy to LEARN, but hard to MASTER gameplay. This all nicely shown in a pixel art style that representative, fun and appealling.---New review:First off: This is one of the best Early Acces game releases, probably the best. With their mentality to really get everything out of EA they went and did it. Every Tuesday and Thursday on of the team was streaming: showing new projects in the developent, streaming the game, having fun with new ideas, testing new features, answering questions. They have truelly been an inspiration for me in the past 1.5 years I have followed them develop this game. We were able to see it from beginning to end and we got delivered what they were promised.The Good:- The game play: it's fast and fun- Instant gratification: Jump right into the action, no bla bla. (If you get the joke, well done).Lot's of characters, weapons and MUTATIONS: so many combinations to try out, you keep combining and you have to, as everything is randomly found.- Good challenge: If you're not a very skilled player, this game is still fun, you will still have a feeling of achievement after ending a run. For the high skilled: try staying alive when you are looped! More bosses, more environments, harder enemies!- Audio: The reason I bought the game. The rough sounds gives a tough feel, a super attitude to a game that oozes with action. Every gun feels better.- Price: €12,99, that's not pricey for a single/co-op game.The Bad: - Crashes: Game crashes when immediately leaving the co-op menu, after entering.- Stats: Stats do not load.The Ugly:- Some graphic bugs: Shovel looks weird, sometimes a glitch.Conclusion:I highly recommend this game, if you like top down shooters, guns blazing, rough audio, a cool soundtrack and EXPLOSIONS! So much fun and hard to get through. You'll easily get you money out of it! Thanks JW + Rami (Vlambeer) and team.

content:
26, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a fantastic Rogue-Like top down shooter, with 12 different characters to play as, and a very huge assortment of weapons to find and choose from! I genuinely enjoy this game, it's just fantastic and absorbs you slowly from the inside out. My favorite character, Steroids, has the special ability to hold and fire two weapons which leads to very insane and fun runs. Every character has their own passives and actives such as Crystal's ability to shield and Fish can roll, leaving lots of opportunities for very fun and interesting runs. My only two complaints would be that while there is indeed co-op, it's limited to being on the same computer which isn't very fun in my opinion due to most of my friends who play NT live elsewhere. My other complaint would be the lack of modding allowed in the most recent versions of the game, which in my opinion would make the game WAY more fun and with huge amounts of variety.But despite those downfalls, it's still a fantastic game worth your rightfully earned money. Will you reach the Nuclear Throne?There is no yeti.

content:
6
												This is such a good game. It's very hard, but it's incredibly rare I don't have a great time playing it.I'm not even sure how to describe the overall vibe. Yeah okay it's a twin stick bullet hell shooter with random level generation, blah blah. But it feels like someone loved Gauntlet, and Borderlands, and one day said WHY NOT BOTH.And indeed, why ever not?Many of your runs (especially in the first few hours) will be under five minutes. Some WELL UNDER. But as you keep hammering away it does get a bit easier. Slowly, ever so slowly.It's so good. I don't know if I'm doing justice to how much fun I have playing this.Great soundtrack too.

ber 12, 2016
												I understand how it feels to have no progression but the reason that they put so many acheivements and characters at the start is because they want to give you a taste of what its like. And they put the characters there so you aren't stuck with a sertain playstyle until youre good with that specific style because they want you to explore and give you something  else to do if youcve given up on one character. But overall I think the reason that you don't feel like youre progressing is either because you haven't played long enough to give the game a chance or its because youre bad at the game(as stupid as it sounds but hear me out) and youve given up because you cant get the character you need. And I COMPLETELY UNDERSTAND how that feels because its anoying and hard to deal with. But I decided not to give up and Ive know the game since update 2 and my average was dying in the sewers but now that I started again I am able to get to the palace and I have all but 2 locked characters(minus ball guy and skeleton). I think what anyone who wants to get into thise game would want to at least try theyre best to unlock characters for their style of play and roll with those characters for a decent amount of time.
